DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Caesar glowered amid the holiday cheer. The gorilla clambered up the rocks and squatted, turning out his lower lip in displeasure as the family ate its presents and a few trees on Tuesday. Caesar's gloom was probably caused by a cold, but if the illness was catching, his disposition wasn't. The rest of the gorilla family and the family in the compound next door smelled the roses and promptly ate them. The two families of gorillas at the Los Angeles Zoo were released from their quarters at midmorning to find their compounds were strewn with popcorn balls, cranberries, bougainvilleas, rawhide chews and fruit. Banana trees decorated with purple, orange and yellow roses and sprinkled with coconut snow stood outside the grottos, with boxed presents all around. Burlap stockings were placed by the rocks with care, filled with nuts and squash and all sorts of goodies. The holiday party was the work of volunteers from the Gorilla Garden, which grows supplemental foods for the zoo's dozen gorillas. ``They enjoy it because a lot of their really special favorite treats are out there,'' said Jennifer Chatfield, the gorillas' keeper. ``They also have some things they don't usually get _ like a whole banana tree.''

Dave Lebiuk says he swims only once a year _ the day after Christmas _ so he likes to make it last. That's why he was the last person out of the water Tuesday during the annual ``polar bear'' swim at this Vancouver Island city. The 35-year-old spent 30 minutes in the 50-degree waters of Departure Bay. ``I started four years ago or more and I just keep doing it,'' he said as he dried off before heading for a hot tub set up on the beach. The 196 participants who braved the chilly waters ranged in age from 2-year-old Mary Rice to 76-year-old Patrick O'Rooney. Swimmers receive a silver dollar and polar bear pin for their efforts. ``It's fun, but I think they're crazy,'' said 12-year-old Esther McDonnall, who was visiting from Australia.
